channel.description: Pona Bana le Blog de l'Unicef en RDCongo

wp:category.wp:category_description:
Retrouvez tous les articles écrits par des enfants de RDC et du monde entier!
Les articles publiés représentent l’opinion de leurs auteurs et n’engagent pas la responsabilité de l’UNICEF.
Retrouvez les principaux chiffres clefs sur la situation en RD Congo classés par thème
Retrouvez les derniers communiqués de presse publiés par l'UNICEF en RDC

Each subject begins with the opportunity to show a block of text that describes the subject and gives an overview and context to the individual posts to follow. Retrouvez des dessins réalisés par des enfants de République Démocratique du Congo et d'ailleurs!
Vous avez moins de 18 ans et l'un des thèmes suivants vous inspire? RD Congo - Protection - Santé - Education - Eau - Participation - Bonheur - Famille - Maison ?
Envoyez nous votre dessin à: info@ponabana.com Nous publierons les dessins sélectionnés dans cette section!
Parlez-en aussi à vos amis et dans vos classes!

En RDC comme partout dans le monde, l’UNICEF s’emploie à améliorer l’approvisionnement en eau et les installations sanitaires des écoles et des collectivités et à promouvoir des pratiques hygiéniques. Nous apportons notre soutien à de multiples et diverses activités et coopérons avec de nombreux partenaires, dont des familles, des collectivités, des gouvernements et des organisations porteuses des mêmes valeurs.
En situation d'urgence, nous apportons des secours d’urgence aux collectivités et nations risquant de ne plus être approvisionnées en eau et menacées par des maladies. Tous les programmes de l’UNICEF en matière d’eau et d’assainissement sont conçus pour contribuer à la réalisation de l’Objectif du Millénaire pour le développement lié à l’eau et à l’assainissement : réduire de moitié, d’ici à 2015, la proportion de personnes n’ayant pas durablement accès à l’eau salubre et à des installations sanitaires de base.

Savoir pour Sauver a pour but de donner aux familles et aux communautés les informations dont elles ont besoin pour protéger les enfants et améliorer leur existence.
Les parents, les grands parents, les personnes qui s’occupent d’enfants et les jeunes peuvent consulter cette source d’informations pratiques pour y trouver les réponses à leurs questions et apprendre comment donner aux enfants le meilleur départ dans la vie.
Les messages regroupés dans Savoir pour Sauver se fondent sur les découvertes scientifiques les plus récentes et sur les droits de l’homme, en particulier la Convention relative aux droits de l’enfant et la Convention pour l’élimination de toutes les formes de discrimination à l’égard des femmes.
Tout le monde peut faire passer les messages de Savoir pour Sauver!

Rapports publiés par l'UNICEF sur la situation humanitaire en République Démocratique du Congo (en anglais).
Retrouvez les dernières évolutions politiques et sécuritaires, chiffres clefs ainsi que les actions menées par l'UNICEF et de ses partenaires classées par secteur.

Un village assaini, qu’est-ce que c’est? 1. Un village ayant un comité dynamique 2. Au moins 80 % de la population a accès à l’eau potable 3. Au moins 80 % des ménages utilisent une latrine hygiénique 4. Au moins 80 % des parcelles sont propres 5. Au moins 60 % de la population se lave les mains avec du savon ou de la cendre avant de manger et après avoir été aux toilettes 6. Au moins 70 % de la population comprend le schéma de transmission des maladies à partir des matières fécales et es mesures de prévention 7. Le village est nettoyé au moins une fois par mois
Et une école assainie ? 1. 100 % du personnel enseignant formé à la stratégie « École Assainie », en Education à la Santé et à l’Environnement, et 100 % du COPA sensibilisé 2. 80 % de manuels pour élèves disponibles : 1 manuel pour 2 élèves ou 1 guide par enseignant 3. 1 porte pour 40 filles et 1 porte pour 50 garçons et 80 % de latrines hygiéniques 4. 100 % d’eau potable disponible et 80 % d’élèves se lavant les mains avec du savon ou de la cendre 5. 1 fois par jour, cour d’école et salles de classe sont balayées/nettoyées et déchets jetés dans un trou à ordure 6. 100 % des brigadiers de santé et d’environnement élus dans les écoles sensibilisés et Opérationnels
L’approche “Village assaini” pas à pas 0. La communauté prend connaissance du programme et décide collectivement d’y adhérer, puis soumet une demande formelle a la zone de sante. 1. Signature du protocole d’accord entre la communauté et la zone de sante. 2. La communauté élit un comité de village après que la zone de sante ait forme une ving-taine de volontaires sur ce point. 3. Les acteurs de la zone de sante réalisent une enquête sur les comportements, attitudes et pratiques des ménages du village. 4. La communauté analyse ses conditions d’hygiène et d’assainissement, grâce à la carto-graphie communautaire, la promenade d’observation, le classement de dessins des conditions d’hygiène en 3 catégories et l’analyse des voies de transmission féco-orales. 5. La communauté élabore son Plan d’action communautaire, en classant les interventions décidées par priorités. 6. La communauté met en oeuvre les activités nécessaires pour améliorer son accès à l’eau et l’assainissement. Les volontaires font la promotion des bonnes pratiques d’hygiène. 7. L’enquête finale : le bureau de la zone de santé réalise une étude des nouvelles connais-sances, attitudes et pratiques acquises par la communauté. 8. Le médecin-chef de zone vérifie si le village a atteint les normes exigées pour être déclaré Village Assaini. Si c’est le cas, le médecin accorde son certificat au village au cours d’une célébration.

item.title: NYHQ2005-2204
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Children smile, at a nonformal education centre in Kinsenso, a poor settlement on the outskirts of Kinshasha, the capital. The UNICEF-supported centre provides basic education to children who have left traditional schools for a variety of reasons. Part of the UNICEF logo is visible on the banner behind them.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.

item.title: NYHQ2005-0439
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Boys raise their hands to shield their faces and their identities as former child soldiers, at a UNICEF-supported Centre de Transit et Orientation (CTO), a shelter and reintegration centre for recently demobilized child soldiers, in the eastern town of Goma, capital of North Kivu Province. The CTO provides medical and psychosocial care, as well as family tracing and reunification services. Nationwide, over 33,000 child soldiers remain active.
In March 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), insecurity and massive population displacements continue to challenge relief efforts in the eastern part of the country. An upsurge in violence in the resource-rich Ituri region, including the killing in February of nine MONUC (United Nations Organization Mission in the DRC) peacekeepers, led to a temporary suspension in humanitarian aid to tens of thousands of displaced civilians. Over two-thirds of the displaced are children and women. As aid resumes, the number of displaced continues to grow: up to 88,000 are registered in camps but many more are assumed to be in need of shelter. Some 6 million people throughout the north-eastern region are affected by the ongoing conflict. Hundreds of thousands are victimized in atrocities committed with impunity. Recruitment of child soldiers by all military factions continues. Rape of girls and women is a widespread weapon of war, terrorizing the population and increasing HIV prevalence. This regional fighting is part of a seven-year conflict in which up to 5 million Congolese have died from starvation, disease and warfare. UNICEF is working with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of displaced children and women, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts and other health, water and sanitation, education and protection initiatives in the region.

item.title: NYHQ2000-0680
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
On 11 August 2000, a girl stands with other children in the south-central town of Kananga, where members of the local mobile vaccination team are going from door to door during the NIDs campaign against polio to find children who have not yet been immunized against the virus.
From 10 to 13 August 2000, UNICEF Executive Director Carol Bellamy visited the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), to further global efforts to eradicate polio, especially in countries affected by conflict. One of 20 priority countries where wild poliovirus is still endemic, her visit there coincided with a National Immunization Days (NIDs) campaign targeting 11 million children. Polio eradication efforts in the country are hampered by ongoing armed conflict in six provinces affecting some 14 million Congolese, as both the national economy and health system are deteriorating. Child malnutrition in all parts of the country is rising; some 20,000 children have been recruited as child soldiers and another 20,000 have been separated from their families; 50,000 are living or working on the streets, with some forced into prostitution, including children younger than eight years old; and approximately 210,000 more are internally displaced. During her visit, Ms. Bellamy participated in a NIDs launch, as well as in door-to-door outreach efforts to immunize the 10-20 per cent of children unable to go to the central immunization sites, and met with polio-afflicted children, government representatives and UNICEF staff. This is the second round of polio immunizations in the country in the year 2000; a third round is scheduled for September. Each child must be immunized three times to be fully protected from the polio virus.

item.content:encoded:

From 10 to 13 August 2000, UNICEF Executive Director Carol Bellamy visited the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), to further global efforts to eradicate polio, especially in countries affected by conflict. item.title: NYHQ2005-2126
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
A girl waits at a health centre in Kisangani, capital of the north-eastern Province Orientale. UNICEF provides the centre with essential drugs and vaccines, medical supplies, mosquito bednets for pregnant women and children under five, training for health workers, as well as bicycles and motor bikes for outreach and supervision.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. item.title: Children gather to play and learn at one of the three Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF Education/Child Protection partner RHA in Punia. Offering a safe place to gather outside of school, the CFS can serve as a point of refuge and one in which to share and overcome that which they may have experienced in the course of conflict and displacement. Following heavy fighting in early 2013 between the Raia Mutomboki (RM) rebel group and the Congolese Army (FARDC) more than 55,000 people were displaced into the forests and indigenous villages of Punia Territory, Maniema Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo. Despite the logistical challenges of providing aid in an area inaccessible by car, and with persistent threats to security, UNICEF RRMP partner NRC immediately intervened to provide a multi-sectorial evaluation (MSA) allowing for a coordinated, rapid response between UN, INGO and Local NGO partners. By July, In addition to the rehabilitation/construction of 15 water sources, establishment of 22 water chlorination points and construction of 48 latrines, UNICEF partners succeeded in providing emergency non-food item (NFI) support to more then 5,700 households (approximately 28,000 people) emergency health services to more than 15,000 and Education / Child Protection support to the teachers and pupils of 65 separate schools in the affected area. With the area now largely under the control of the national authorities the vast majority of the population has returned home.
item.dc:creator: adrien

item.title: Children gather to observe the start of the three-day national vaccination campaign in the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp, North Kivu, DRC.Together with representatives of the DRC Ministry of Health, the WHO and local partners, UNICEF launched the North Kivu portion of the three-day National Polio Vaccination Campaign on July 11th at the Mugunga 1 Internal Displacement Camp outside Goma. Country-wide the vaccination campaign aims to immunize 16.3 million children aged 0-5 years against Polio, taking the occasion to also provide Vitamin A supplementation and deworming pills to the children and register children under 3 months with the civil authorities. Within North Kivu Province, the campaign has set out to immunize 1.3 million children.Since the launch in 1988 of the Global Initiative to Eradicate Polio, coordinated by the governments of countries concerned, WHO, UNICEF, Rotary International and the CDC-Atlanta, the 350,000 children paralyzed annually by Polio has been reduced by more than 99% while reducing the number of endemic countries from 125 to 3. Participating in the immunization campaigns since 1998, the DRC has seen a steady reduction of polio cases, and has now been polio-free since December 2011.
item.dc:creator: adrien

item.title: March 16, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. ?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
March 16, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.
Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center.
“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”

The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.
Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center.
?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?";}}

item.title: On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.
item.dc:creator: adrien

item.title: March 16, 2013Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRCUNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program ? co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando. From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families. Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations. Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center. ?I?m really content with what I purchased,? Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. ?Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
March 16, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.
Agathe, 30, fled her home in Mwimbili village in February when fighting broke out between the Raia Mutomboki and FARDC. After returning briefly in March, she fled again with her husband and three children in April, seeking shelter with a host family in Mwenga Center.
“I’m really content with what I purchased,” Agathe explained of the basins, saucepans and clothing she purchased at the fair. “Most importantly, I can now prepare food for the family.”

item.title: Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu. Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu. Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence ? Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Children play at the Child Friendly Space (CFS) operated by UNICEF partner AVSI in the Bulengo IDP site. The CFS provide a safe environment for children to gather for recreational and educational activities while not in school.
A delegation of Emergency Directors including UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, OCHA Operations Director John Ging, UN Humanitarian Coordinator in DRC Moustapha Soumare and high-level representatives from WFP, WHO, FAO and UNHCR visited the Bulengo Spontaneous Site just outside Goma on Tuesday, October 22, 2013 to witness the multi-agency humanitarian response in the largest single displacement site in North Kivu.
Home to approximately 55,000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Bulengo has experienced a massive influx of IDPs since November 2012 when thousands fled towards Goma during fighting between the M23 and Congolese Army (FARDC). Since then, numerous waves of displacement have resulted from clashes between the FARDC and M23, Nyatura and APCLS rebel groups. Coming mainly from the Masisi and Rutshuru territories, the IDPs in Bulengo represent some of the more than 1 million currently displaced in North Kivu.
Coordinated by IOM and managed by Première Urgence – Aide Médicale International (PU-AMI) and Danish Refugee Council (DRC) residents of the Bulengo Site have received Non-Food Item (NFI) support from the UNICEF-OCHA RRMP in December 2012, Food and Nutrition support from WFP and World Vision, Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) support from Oxfam and Mercy Corps, Education and Child Protection support from UNICEF partner AVSI and Health support from MSF Belgium.

Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:5:{s:5:"width";i:647;s:6:"height";i:462;s:4:"file";s:18:"2013/11/rrmp23.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:18:"rrmp23-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:18:"rrmp23-300x214.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:214;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1376655183;s:9:"copyright";s:25:"© UNICEF RDC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:1123:"On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.";}}

item.title: Profil bloggeur_Brett Morton
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
March 15, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

item.title: Profil bloggeur_Ndiaga Seck
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma… 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site… Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.
In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites.
With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages. NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.

item.title: UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme. Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach. A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict. In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.

This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.

a:5:{s:5:"width";i:591;s:6:"height";i:457;s:4:"file";s:42:"2013/12/Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton21.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:42:"Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton21-150x150.jpg";s:5:"width";i:150;s:6:"height";i:150;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}s:6:"medium";a:4:{s:4:"file";s:42:"Profil-bloggeur_Brett-Morton21-300x231.jpg";s:5:"width";i:300;s:6:"height";i:231;s:9:"mime-type";s:10:"image/jpeg";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";i:0;s:6:"credit";s:12:"Brett Morton";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:2068:"March 15, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.
Since late 2012, fighting between rebels of the Raia Mutomboki and the Congolese Army (FARDC) has lead to the displacement of more than 6,000 families around the village of Ngando, South Kivu, DRC. With more than 2.6 million currently displaced across eastern DRC, the Rapid Response to Movements of Populations (RRMP) program – co-lead by UNICEF and OCHA and implemented by 6 INGO partners - aims to assist the most vulnerable of those affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters, such as those of Ngando.
From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners’ relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This “Fair Approach” represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1368635248;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:2060:"March 15, 2013 Kionvu, Mwenga, South Kivu, DRC UNICEF RRMP partner AVSI carries out NFI Fair.

From February - April 2013, 6 rapid needs assessments were conducted by RRMP partner AVSI in villages surrounding Ngando. Approximately 3,300 of the most vulnerable families were identified to receive support through a Non-Food Item (NFI) Fair carried out over the course of 5 days in May near Mwenga Center, where the majority of displaced from Ngando had settled with host families.
Providing essential household items and emergency shelter materials has been a core component of UNICEF and partners? relief programs for displaced, returning displaced and other disaster-affected populations since 2004. Building upon existing relief programs for emergency-affected populations which include a significant NFI component, UNICEF and partners created the cash-based voucher NFI fair approach to allow beneficiaries to select goods and supplies according to their own priorities, leading to improved efficiency in NFI assistance and as well as greater participation of affected populations.
Operating in essence as a local market, beneficiaries are given cash vouchers, which vendors can then redeem for cash following the closure of the fair. The participating households are free to choose the items which will serve them best, while the local economy is reinforced through the participation of local vendors. This ?Fair Approach? represented more than 50% of RRMP NFI distributions in 2012, and is scheduled to account for 60% in 2013.";}}

item.title: NFI Header
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: IRC DRC RRMP WaSH Intervention. 13 March, 2013. - -Mwateganyi, 45, married mother of 4 children – Agnes, 15 – Namwigima, 10 – Faida, 5 – Bulonza, 1 -Displaced since January 5th from Maziba (towards Luntukulu) when fighting broke out between RM and FARDC -This is the 5th time they’ve been displaced. First time was in ’98. In 2002 it was MaiMai vs. RCD. -Staying in the home of Zihalirwa, who has hosted them each of the times they’ve been displaced as he is a family friend. -“When we heard the shots we fled fearing for our lives. We had to leave everything behind, and took only the little we could carry immediately.” -They left on foot, walking for about one day to cover the 15-20 km. -The first difficulty is always the stress of dying. And then the risks along the route. The sickness of the children is a problem also. All the children fell sick by the time we arrived. -In Maziba they are farmers. -“When we return home we already know everything will be missing or destroyed. The last time they even took the doors of the house.” -“Here the big need is to find food. And clothes. And cooking utensils, and jerrycans. And the health of the children is very difficult.” -The NFI kit is very important. We can use the sheeting when we return to use as a roof. The husband has already returned to begin rebuilding. The blanked and mat are good to have here and upon return. With the clothes the children can go to church. The pots and pans are so helpful because before we had to wait for others to finish using the pots and pans before we could start cooking. For everything else it was necessary to rely on the kindness of others to give us, but they don’t have much so it is difficult for them to give. -The water source is very important. Before we had the latrine all the children had diarrhea. We had to wait for 1-2 hours at the water point to fetch water because of the crowds. Now there are no crowds. -Ziahlirwa explains that as a host family it becomes very difficult for him also because they have little to give. -This is the first time they have received any aid with the displaced. -“Thanks to the displaced I now have a latrine and clean water! I never had a proper latrine before, so it’s very nice.” -When asked why he hosts the displaced, ZIahlirwa explained that “ One day I could also be displaced.”

I never had a proper latrine before, so it’s very nice.” -When asked why he hosts the displaced, ZIahlirwa explained that “ One day I could also be displaced.”";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1363253137;s:9:"copyright";s:29:"© UNICEF RDC / 2013 / Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}

item.title: UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme. Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach. A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict. In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d’Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.
PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors’ capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.
Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+’s approach.
A more explicit relationship with UNICEF’s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF’s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict. In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.

Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+’s approach.
A more explicit relationship with UNICEF’s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF’s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict. In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.";s:17:"created_timestamp";i:1384425635;s:9:"copyright";s:25:"© UNICEF RDC/2013/Morton";s:12:"focal_length";i:0;s:3:"iso";i:0;s:13:"shutter_speed";i:0;s:5:"title";s:2102:"UNICEF Deputy Representative Sylvie Fouet visits PEAR+ (Programme Elargi d?Assistance aux Retours) activities in the Matanda area of South Kivu.
PEAR Plus provides an integrated package of assistance and capacity building to communities; local and state authorities in the sectors of Health, Water, Hygiene and Sanitation, Education and Child Protection.Sectorial specific activities include the following: School reconstruction, support to transparent and equitable structure management, teacher-training, support to parent/teacher associations, provision of education kits and didactic material. Restoration and development of sustainable access to safe water and healthy environment; rehabilitation of health centres, reinforcement of health staff and directors? capacities; provision of basic medical necessities; support to vaccination campaigns and community-based treatment for malnutrition as well as the identification and strengthening child protection networks and responses are all part of the Programme.
Accompanied by peacebuilding activities and interventions designed to improve social cohesion, emphasis is put on governance activities (linked to social service provision) and conflict risk reduction in order to keep the Programme relevant to the evolving context and consequent needs. Increased community participation and ownership, as well as a reinforcement of the social contract between community, local and state authorities are increasingly key outputs of PEAR+?s approach.
A more explicit relationship with UNICEF?s long term programming provides a clear exit strategy and guarantees a degree of sustainability in the medium term, whilst a closer alignment with UNICEF?s emergency response mechanisms and the integration of sectorial emergency preparedness helps improve community resilience to the impact of conflict. In recognition of the fluid nature in the east, the objective is to develop a way of working which supports social and economic rehabilitation; reinforces community resilience and eases the transition to emergency assistance or longer term support.";}}

item.title: Sotraki Temporary Site, Goma? 8th CEPAC, a local NGO operating in Goma distributes BP-5 buscuits and Plumpy nut to malnourished children living in the Sotraki site? Following months of relative peace after the takeover of Goma by the M23 rebels in November, 2012, fighting once again broke out on the edge of Goma between the M23 and the Congolese Army (FARDC) in May, 2013. Upwards of 6,000 people fled their homes towards the city center, where they sought shelter in schools, churches, or with host families.In response to the displacement the humanitarian community mobilized resources to create numerous temporary sites to cater to the displaced. UNICEF coordinated with partners Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC) and Norwegian Church Aid (NCA) to provide shelter and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene as well as logistical support to the management of the sites. With more than 1,700 families staying at the Sotraki site (as of 04 June, 2013) UNICEF partner NCA responded within one week of the displacement to construct 16 latrines,12 showers, and instal a 30m3 water bladder which provides a constant flow to 12 taps in the site. In addition, NCA hygiene teams have organized and supervised the regular cleaning of the latrines, as well as spreading general hygiene messages.NRC has contributed to the establishment of numerous tents in which to hose the displaced in both the Sotraki and Buhimba sites. In addition, through UNICEF RRMP funds, NRC has provided transportation of displaced to the Buhimba site in an effort to decongest the Sotraki site. Plans are underway for an NFI distribution to be carried out through UNICEF RRMP partners NRC and Slidarités International.

item.title: On August 16, 2013 UNICEF and Merlin, with the support of ECHO and UNHASS delivered 3.5 tons of medical/nutritional supplies to Nobili, North Kivu, DRC, as part of the OCHA/UNICEF led RRMP program. Following attacks on Kamongo by the ADF-Nalu rebels in July, more than 66,000 people were displaced from their homes in to surrounding villages in DRC and neighboring Uganda. RRMP assessments in late July revealed a 550% increase in child mortality and nearly 50% prevelance of diarrhea in children under 5. With many displaced settling in Nobili, approximately 9 km from Kamongo, the population more than tripled from 8,500 residents to 30,500. The hosiptal and health centers were looted during the attacks, leaving little resources to combat disease and malnutrition. Immediately following the distribution of supplies Merlin opened mobile health clinics in the area and began support to the hospital and area health centers, and together with UNICEF, the Ministry of Health and Lutheran World Federation (LWF) began a five-day measles vaccination campaign targeting more than 45,000 displaced and host-community children.
item.dc:creator: Justine

item.title: The ECHO-funded UNHAS helicopter departs Kasika, Mwenga Territory.__The IASC Emergency Directors Group visit humanitarian activities in Mwenga, Territory, South Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Thursday, October 24, 2013.With numerous armed confrontations continuing in eastern DRC, more than 2.7 million are currently displaced. The visit of Emergency Directors, including OCHA Operations Director John Ging and UNICEF Director of Emergency Programs Ted Chaiban, among others, is meant to help create a shared understanding of challenges within the various humanitarian agencies present, as well as to help identify solutions to operational gaps. Traveling by ECHO-funded helicopter to Kasika, Mwenga, the Directors delegation visited an ECHO-funded Food Fair implemented by AVSI, a FAO-funded food security project, a health center supported by UNICEF carrying out support to malnourished children, as well as a food distribution funded by WFP and implemented by World Vision.
item.dc:creator: Justine

item.title: UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilitiesGoma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - ?The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it?s very difficult for him to walk,? says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal. ?He?s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,? Vumilia adds. 8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand. The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu?s capital Goma. He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December. Restoring dignityThere are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC. Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities. So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF?s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. ?Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,? underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. ?Their dignity is restored,? she adds.RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters?including host families?while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families. In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services.The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma. ?Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,? Katungo explains. ?That?s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,? she adds. Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin.[END]
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
UNICEF assists internally displaced persons with disabilities Goma, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 25 May 2013 - “The wheelchair Meshak has received is very important as it’s very difficult for him to walk,” says Aline Vumilia, 22, as Meshak Batundi sits in a wheelchair for the first time and starts learning how to pedal. “He’s also received an adapted toilet because his access to public latrines is difficult too,” Vumilia adds.
8-year old Meshak walks on his knees because he contracted a disease that maimed his two feet and his right hand. The young boy lives with his aunt Aline at Lac Vert Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) site near North Kivu’s capital Goma. He was separated from his mother when armed conflict reached his village of Kitchanga last December.
Restoring dignity There are hundreds of people with disabilities amongst the thousands of displaced people who have settled around Goma, having fled from armed conflict in North Kivu, eastern DRC. Basic services available at the IDP site pose accessibility problems to people with disabilities. So, additional measures are required to make sure that these people have equal access to facilities and are able to live with dignity. Through the Rapid Response to Population Movements (RRMP) mechanism, UNICEF’s partner, Handicap International, distributes items such as crutches, walking canes, wheelchairs and adapted toilets. “Now that they move on wheelchairs, these people who used to walk on all fours can get together with people more easily,” underlines Odette Katungo, a Handicap International physiotherapist. “Their dignity is restored,” she adds. RRMP assisted over 1.5 million conflict-affected people in 2012 The RRMP delivers an integrated assistance to acutely vulnerable populations affected by displacement, return and/or natural disasters—including host families—while there are sites of displaced persons in some provinces, like Nord Kivu where Meshak and his aunt live, over 80% of IDPs in the D.R.Congo do not live in sites or camps, but with host families. In partnership with OCHA and through seven stand-by INGO partners in Province Orientale, Katanga, North and South Kivu provinces, RRMP assisted over 1.5 million emergency-affected people in 2012 with access to water, hygiene and sanitation, essential household items, education and health services. The UNICEF/Handicap International RRMP project targets 300 displaced persons with disabilities living at Lac Vert and Bulengo, two IDP sites on the outskirts of Goma. “Among the displaced people here, there are persons living with disabilities who find it difficult to move or use the latrines,” Katungo explains. “That’s why Handicap International decided to provide them with different types of items to assist with mobility and walking,” she adds. Displaced people living with disabilities are among the most vulnerable. UNICEF and its partners aim at reducing such vulnerability and improve their living conditions on the IDP sites or with host families until peace and security allow for their return to their villages of origin. [END]

item.title: Elena Locatelli :C'est avec une grande joie que l'UNICEF s'associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé comme donateur direct avec l'UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d?équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d'ici à mi-2015. A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d'achat, à travers la centrale d'achat de l'UNICEF à Copenhague.Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l'UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s'élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé à financer.L'acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L'UNICEF est responsable pour l'ensemble de la chaine d'approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu'au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l'entreposage, le conditionnement, l'évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l'installation dans les sites. Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d?être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population. L'espoir de l'UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité. Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l'avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d?enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d?ici fin 2015.Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l'encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l?enfant dans le cadre de l?approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
Elena Locatelli :
C'est avec une grande joie que l'UNICEF s'associe ce jour à Goma à la remise officielle symbolique des matériels et équipements par le Ministre de la Santé Publique, au Gouverneur de la province du Nord Kivu.
Pour la première fois, le Gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé comme donateur direct avec l'UNICEF à acheter, dans le cadre du Projet d’équipement des structures sanitaires (PESS), les équipements médicaux pour couvrir les besoins en matériels médico-sanitaires de 200 hôpitaux généraux de référence et 1000 centres de santé dans les 11 provinces du pays en trois phases d'ici à mi-2015.
A ce stade, dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2, les équipements pour 132 hôpitaux et 660 centres de santé ont été livrés ou sont en cours d'achat, à travers la centrale d'achat de l'UNICEF à Copenhague.
Le volume financier contribué par le gouvernement à travers l'UNICEF dans le cadre des phases 1 et 2 s'élève à 29.8 millions de dollars américains.
La troisième phase, planifiée pour 2014, ciblera 68 Hôpitaux et 340 centres de sante additionnels et coutera 22 millions de dollars, que le gouvernement de RDC s'est engagé à financer.
L'acheminement des équipements a représenté des défis, avec environ 140 containers de 40 pieds (67 mètres cubes) expédies par bateaux et partiellement par avions en RDC pour la première phase seule, et 420 containers attendus au total pour les trois phases. L'UNICEF est responsable pour l'ensemble de la chaine d'approvisionnement depuis la commande, jusqu'au transport maritime et aerien, a la réception et l'entreposage, le conditionnement, l'évaluation techniques des structures cibles, la distribution in-country, et la formation des bénéficiaires finaux pendant l'installation dans les sites.
Les matériels et équipements qui viennent d’être remis par le Ministère de la santé Publique vont renforcer le système de santé et aider à une meilleure prise en charge de la population.
L'espoir de l'UNICEF est que grâce à cette volonté politique nationale forte, tous les enfants et leurs mamans, même ceux des zones les plus reculées de RDC puissent avoir accès aux soins de qualité permettant de vaincre les principales causes de mortalité.
Ces efforts du gouvernement congolais sont une contribution significative à la « promesse renouvelée » pour l'avancement du pays vers les OMD 4 et 5, qui vise à sauver 430 000 vies d’enfants de 0 à 5 ans et 7 900 vies de mères d’ici fin 2015.
Nous saisissons cette occasion pour féliciter le gouvernement et l'encourager à poursuivre ses efforts en faveur de la santé de la mère et de l’enfant dans le cadre de l’approche « Naître, grandir, progresser ».

item.title: Answer for Combien d'enfants reporters y a-t-il en RDC?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: L'UNICEF, en partenariat avec le Ministère du Genre, Famille, Enfants de la RDC a mis en place le programme "Enfants Reporters" dans les 11 provinces du pays. Depuis 2007, près de 500 enfants ont participé au programme et ont reçu une formation de base en production audiovisuelle et en techniques de plaidoyer pour la défense des droits de l’enfant.

item.title: Answer for Is this really a good tool?
item.dc:creator: ponobono
item.content:encoded: Yes it is

item.title: Answer for Is this really a good tool?
item.dc:creator: ponobono

item.title: Combien d'enfants reporters y a-t-il en RDC?
item.dc:creator: Eunice

item.title: Combien de personnes sont déplacées en RDC?
item.dc:creator: marc
item.content:encoded: Bonjour j'aimerai savoir combien de personnes sont déplacées en RDC?

item.title: Answer for Combien de personnes sont déplacées en RDC?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: Au mois d'octobre 2013, la population déplacée interne atteignait 2.7 millions de personnes (Source: OCHA). 60% résident au Nord et au Sud Kivu, à l’Est du pays. C'est 1 million de plus qu’en 2011. Plus de la moitié sont des enfants.  Vous trouverez plus d'informations à ce sujet sur notre page "Urgences" http://ponabana.com/urgences/

item.title: Est-ce que tous les enfants vont à l'école ?
item.dc:creator: Nathan
item.content:encoded: je voudrais savoir si tous les enfants vont à l'école au Congo?

item.title: Answer for Est-ce que tous les enfants vont à l'école ?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: En RDC, 7,4 millions d'enfants entre 5 et 17 ans ne vont pas à l'école. (Source: Out of school Study 2012) 52% sont des filles, 48% des garçons. Cela est surtout dû au fait que les frais pour étudier sont très élevés pour les familles. L’étude "Out of school" réalisée en 2012 sur les enfants non scolarisés montre qu’il existe un lien direct entre la scolarisation des enfants et les revenus d’un foyer.  Il y a néanmoins eu beaucoup de progrès ces dernières années. Si ces efforts sont maintenus il est possible de faire en sorte que tous les enfants aient accès à l'éducation. Vous trouverez plus d'informations à ce sujet sur cette page: http://ponabana.com/education-2/education-chiffres-clefs/

item.title: Comment faire pour postuler à l'Unicef RDC?
item.dc:creator: john
item.content:encoded: Bonjour, J'aimerai travailler pour l'Unicef RDC. Comment faire?

item.title: Answer for Comment faire pour postuler à l'Unicef RDC?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: Bonjour, Il y a deux types de postes: - Les postes internationaux pour tous les candidats excepté ceux de la RDC - Les postes nationaux exclusivement reservés aux candidats de la RDC Ces postes sont publiés en ligne aux adresses suivantes: - Site UNICEF(www.unicef.org) - Tous les bureaux UNICEF à travers la RDC,  agences UN et ONGs internationales - Radio OKAPI (www.radiookapi.net) - Reliefweb(www.reliefweb.int) - OCHA (www.rdc-humanitaire.net) - Unjoblist.org - Unjobs.org Notre spécialiste en ressource humaines prépare un article détaillé à ce sujet, restez connecté pour en savoir plus!

item.title: Merci!
item.dc:creator: Khif
item.content:encoded: Merci de votre franche collaboration en RDC! Aidons nos eleves à de fournitures scolaires surtout ceux qui sont au fin fon de la rdc.

item.title: Answer for Que veut dire Pona Bana?
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: "Pona Bana" veut dire "Pour les enfants" en Lingala. En swahili cela se dit "Dju ya watoto" En tshiluba c'est "Bwa bana" Et en kikongo : "Samu Na Bana"

item.title: EN TANT QUE CHEF SCOUT ET ENCADREUR DES JEUNES J'AIMERAIS COLLABORER AVEC VOUS COMME VOLONTAIRE DANS DES MICROPROJETS EN PARTENARIAT AVEC LA COMMUNAUTE LOCALES QUI EN SERONS AUSSI BENEFICIAIRES COMME LES ENFANTS . L'OBJECTIF PRIICIPALE EST LA PARTICIPATION DES JEUNES POUR LA PROTECTION DE LA BIODIVERSITE ET LA LUTTE CONTRE LA PAUVRETE EN MILIEU RURALE. NOUS AVONS ELABORE UN MICROPROJET EN APICULTURE AINSI QUE DIVERSES ACTIVITES CONNEXES CLQUER SUR CE LIEN POUE EN SAVOIR DAVANTAGE https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5Xa8EWH0FI4UXdsZ0t5SklVS3M/edit?usp=sharing
item.dc:creator: johnson

item.title: Answer for EN TANT QUE CHEF SCOUT ET ENCADREUR DES JEUNES J'AIMERAIS COLLABORER AVEC VOUS COMME VOLONTAIRE DANS DES MICROPROJETS EN PARTENARIAT AVEC LA COMMUNAUTE LOCALES QUI EN SERONS AUSSI BENEFICIAIRES COMME LES ENFANTS . L'OBJECTIF PRIICIPALE EST LA PARTICIPATION DES JEUNES POUR LA PROTECTION DE LA BIODIVERSITE ET LA LUTTE CONTRE LA PAUVRETE EN MILIEU RURALE. NOUS AVONS ELABORE UN MICROPROJET EN APICULTURE AINSI QUE DIVERSES ACTIVITES CONNEXES CLQUER SUR CE LIEN POUE EN SAVOIR DAVANTAGE https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B5Xa8EWH0FI4UXdsZ0t5SklVS3M/edit?usp=sharing
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Bonjour Johnson et merci de votre message. Votre projet est très intéressant. Nous vous conseillons de prendre contact avec le bureau Unicef le plus proche, à Matadi. De nombreuses pistes peuvent être explorées notamment avec les enfants reporters. Voici les contacts du Bureau: Adresse postale : UNICEF, B.P. 39 - Boma/ République Démocratique du Congo
Adresse visiteurs :  Q. Cine Palace, 23 Avenue Pêcherie / Commune de Matadi  - Matadi/Bas-Congo
Téléphone : +243 817151267 
Adresse électronique :matadi@unicef.org Vous pouvez demander à parler à M. Blaise Komy. Bonne journée!

item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Savoir pour Sauver a pour but de donner aux familles et aux communautés les informations dont elles ont besoin pour protéger les enfants et améliorer leur existence.

Les parents, les grands parents, les personnes qui s’occupent d’enfants et les jeunes peuvent consulter cette source d’informations pratiques pour y trouver les réponses à leurs questions et apprendre comment donner aux enfants le meilleur départ dans la vie.

Les messages regroupés dans Savoir pour Sauver se fondent sur les découvertes scientifiques les plus récentes et sur les droits de l’homme, en particulier la Convention relative aux droits de l’enfant et la Convention pour l’élimination de toutes les formes de discrimination à l’égard des femmes.

Tout le monde peut faire passer les messages de Savoir pour Sauver!

item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded: Each subject begins with the opportunity to show a block of text that describes the subject and gives an overview and context to the individual posts to follow. Mirantur deo adiuves finem volo lacrimis V signa ad nomine Maria cum suam ad te princeps coniungitur vestra. Theophile atque ut sua coniuge per. Litus ostendam Apollonio vidit tam gratia de tuae meorum fidelissimi esse deprecor. Solum fuisset delatus defunctam sed dominum
