item.title: Water and Sanitation
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
IMPROVE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

In DRC as in many countries around the world, UNICEF is working to improve water supply and sanitation in schools and communities and to promote hygienic practices . We support multiple and diverse activities and cooperate with many partners, including families, communities, governments and organizations sharing the same values.

INTERVENTION IN EMERGENCIES

We provide emergency assistance to communities and people at risk of not being supplied with water and threatened by disease emergency. All programs of UNICEF's water and sanitation are designed to contribute to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals related to water and sanitation : reduce, by 2015, the proportion of people without sustainable access to safe water and basic sanitation.

item.title: Water and Sanitation - The way forward in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
4 MILLION PEOPLE WILL GAIN ACCESS TO IMPROVED WATER AND SANITATION SERVICES BY 2017

The UNICEF Country Programme 2013-2017 extended the Healthy Villages and Schools program to almost 6,000 villages and 1,500 schools, the equivalent of approximately 4 million people gaining first-time access to improved WASH services.

By September 30, 2019, UNICEF planned to reach 7500 villages which will have committees acting to protect and maintain their healthy environment

The HVHS programme is scaling up to be operational in 250 out of the 515 Health Zones (49%). The second phase of the Healthy Villages and Schools program is focusing on sustainability, including the sustainability of hardware WASH installations; institutional capacity, accountability and obligation, health outcomes, and the scalability of quality results. A strategy is being defined to promote complementarity between the programme and projects of other government institutions, NGOs or the private sector.

To promote transition between emergency and development, new strategies are under discussion within the different stakeholders. UNICEF is also supporting the 2013-2017 New Multisectoral Strategic Plan for the Elimination of Cholera in DRC.

item.title: Water and Sanitation - Key statistics
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
DRC is not on track to reach the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in water and sanitation. The achievement of Goal 7 would require reaching 72% access to drinking water and 58% access to improved sanitation by 2015. Currently 47% of the population has access to safe drinking water (83% urban and 31% rural), while only 14% of the population has access to adequate sanitation facilities (36% urban and 4% rural) according to MICS 2010. Thus to meet the MDGs 17.5 million people in DRC would need to gain access to water and 30.8 million people must gain access to sanitation by 2015.

MAIN KEY STATISTICS

- 47 % of the total population has access to safe drinking water, and 14% access to improved sanitation (MICS 2010).

- In rural areas, water coverage is 31 %; rural improved sanitation 4% (MICS 2010).

- In addition, there are cholera epidemics in endemic cholera prone zone every year in the provinces of Katanga, Oriental, North and South Kivu. DRC is also facing outbreaks in non-endemic areas along the river Congo or cross border with Zambia/Congo Brazzaville. In August 2013, 21 264 cholera cases with 321 deaths have been reported in total and half of them came from Katanga Province and cross-border with Zambia (2014 HNO).

- 2.7 millions of IDP’s are facing challenges to meet their right to get access to safe water, improved sanitation and hygiene

item.title: Water and Sanitation - Key Challenges in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
The water and sanitation sector is weakened by a fragmented political structure. There are currently 6 different government bodies implicated, through 6 separate ministries. Major agencies include: REGIDESO for urban water (Ministry of Energy); National Hydraulic Service for rural water (SNHR), Ministry of Rural Development; PNA for sanitation (Ministry of the Environment) and the 9th Bureau of the Ministry of Health working in both water and sanitation. To facilitate the coordination of the water and sanitation sector, a separate agency, the CNAEA, was created in the 1990s and is based at the Ministry of Planning.

Support was given to the National Committee for Action on Water and Sanitation under the Ministry of Plan (CNAEA), for DRC to join 35 other countries as members of the Sanitation and Water for All initiative. The Government committed at the Washington high level conference in April 2012 to strengthen WASH institutions and related human resources in 2013-2014. UNICEF participates in the WASH Donor Group and the Hygiene Thematic Group. Among the priorities promoted by UNICEF are to push for support to the government strategy on the elimination of cholera in endemic and epidemic areas.

item.title: Water and Sanition - Major achievements in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
In the WASH sector, Unicef and its partner obtained the following results:

1. Increased government capacity and development of national strategies towards improving rural water, sanitation and hygiene throughout 11 provinces and 250 health zones of DRC.

2. The national “Healthy Village and Healthy School” programme follows a community-driven demand-led strategy which gives families the opportunity to make informed choices while strengthening their resilience.

3. At the end of June 2013 the VEA programme was operational in 11 Provinces, 212 Health Zones, and 5289 villages, of which 3256 were certified “Healthy Villages” and 1425 schools, of which 1054 were certified “Healthy Schools”. These results translate into the concrete results of 2,273,198 new persons gaining access to a healthy environment by surpassing minimum water, sanitation and hygiene targets.

4. UNICEF WASH emergency programme assisted more than 800 000 persons in cholera-prone zones with preventive as well as WASH cholera-response packages (MYR Sitrep 2013). With the support of RRMP (Reponse Rapide aux Mouvements de Population, UNICEF DRC’s major emergency programme), 295,144 people were given access to water, sanitation and hygiene in emergency from January to Octobre 2013.

5. In 2013, as UNICEF cluster lead agency for emergency WASH interventions, the WASH Cluster, with their members, coordinated the response to assist more than 4.5 million persons (MYR Sitrep 2013) to get access the WASH packages in order to save life, reduce vulnerability and meet the basic needs.

item.title: Healthy villages and schools
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE

Despite the presence of water resources in the DRC, 51 million Congolese people still lack access to safe drinking water - nearly three-quarters of the country's population. Poor access to drinking water and lack of education on hygiene and sanitation are among the main causes of high morbidity and mortality, especially among children under 5 years.

In order to address these issues water, hygiene and sanitation issues, the DRC government has reinforced its efforts to improve the health conditions in the most vulnerable areas. Thus in 2006 , with the support of its partners including UNICEF, he set up the Healthy Village Programme. An extension to the schools through the Healthy School Programme, has been launched in 2008.

The main objective of the Healthy villages and schools programme is to reduce infant mortality and the spread of water-borne diseases, as well as improve access to drinking water favored in rural and suburban areas.

WHAT IS A HEALTHY VILLAGE ? 1. A village with a dynamic committee 2. At least 80% of the population has access to drinking water 3. At least 80% of households use sanitary latrines 4. At least 80% of plots are clean 5. At least 60% of the population washes their hands with soap or ash before eating and after visiting the latrine 6. At least 70% of the population understands the pattern of disease transmission from fecal matter and the associated preventive measures 7. The village is cleaned at least once a month AND A HEALTHY SCHOOL ? 1. 100% of teachers are trained in the "Healthy Schools" strategy, Health and Environmental Education, and 100% of Parent Involvement Committee members have received awareness training 2. At least 80% of student textbooks are available: 1 textbook for every 2 students or 1 guide per teacher 3. At least 1 entrance for every 40 girls and 1 entrance for every 50 boys, at least 80% of latrines are sanitary 4. 100% availability of drinking water and at least 80% of students wash their hands with soap or ash 5. The schoolyard and classrooms are cleaned once a day and trash is thrown in a refuse pit 6. 100% of health and environment patrollers elected in the schools have received awareness training and are operational A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE TO THE "HEALTHY VILLAGE" APPROACH 1. The community learns of the programme and collectively decides to adopt it, then submits a formal request to the health zone. 2. A statement of agreement between the community and the health zone is signed. 3. The health zone provides training to 20 volunteers, then the community elects a village committee. 4. Health zone officials investigate the behaviours, attitudes and practices of village households. 5. The community analyses its hygiene and sanitation using community mapping, observation walks, 3 categories of classification for hygiene conditions and an analysis of fecal-oral transmission routes. 6. The community develops a Community Action Plan and prioritises interventions. 7. The community takes action to improve access to water and sanitation. Volunteers promote good hygiene practices. 8. The final investigation: the office of the health zone conducts a study of the community's new knowledge, attitudes and practices. 9. The chief medical officer of the health zone checks whether the village meets the standards required to be designated a Healthy Village. If this is the case, the chief medical officer provides the village with a certificate as part of a celebration. You will find more useful information on the healthy village and school official website: www.ecole-village-assainis.cd/‎

item.title: Bloggers
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
[one_third]

Jonathan

  Jonathan is 16 years old and he is a youth reporter Kinshasa. He studied at Saint Joseph College and wants to become a lawyer to defend the children's rights. His dream? That his country "become a country fit for children, a country that respects the rights of the children and put them at the center of everything."

  [/one_third][one_third]

Eunice

Eunice is 14 years old and she is a youth reporter in Kinshasa. She represented Central Africa's children  at the African Union Summit in Addis Ababa in 2012. In her speech to African leaders, she recalled children's rights to survival, freedom of expression, education, health and called for a strategy to prevent armed conflicts which affect the child. Why youth reporter? "Because I want to make my country a better place for children to live."

[/one_third][one_third_last]

Samy

Samy is 10 years old and he is 5th grade in Nsango Magulu Elementary school, 22 km from the town of Kalemie. He is one of the 40 youth reporters trained in the province of North Katanga in August 2013. He lives with his family in the camps for displaced perons of Nsango Magulu and is from Bendera.

 [/one_third_last] [separator] [one_third]

  Rolande

Rolande is 13 years old and she is a  youth reporter in Bandundu. Along with her friends, she is comitted to fight against early marriage and the economic exploitation of children. Later, she will be a teacher to convey what she has learned

  [/one_third][one_third]

 

[/one_third][one_third_last]

 [/one_third_last]

[separator] The articles represent the views of their authors and do not engage the responsibility of UNICEF.

item.title: Education
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: EDUCATION IS A FUNDAMENTAL HUMAN RIGHT Education is a fundamental human right: Every girl and boy in every country is entitled to it. Quality education is critical to development both of societies and of individuals, and it helps pave the way to a successful and productive future. When all children have access to a quality education rooted in human rights and gender equality, it creates a ripple effect of opportunity that influences generations to come. REDUCING INEQUITIES AND DISCRIMINATION Education ends generational cycles of poverty and disease and provides a foundation for sustainable development. A quality basic education equips girls and boys with the knowledge and skills they need to adopt healthy lifestyles, protect themselves from HIV and take an active role in social, economic and political decision-making as they transition to adolescence and adulthood. Educated adults are more likely to have smaller and healthier families, to be informed about appropriate child-rearing practices and to ensure that their children start school on time and ready to learn. Education based on human rights also helps to root out some of society’s persistent inequities. These deprive millions of children, particularly girls, of quality education – and therefore subject them to a life of missed opportunities. Ensuring equity in education builds a foundation for equal opportunity, economic growth, employment creation and productivity. AN OPPORTUNITY TO SURVIVE, DEVELOP AND REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL UNICEF supports development of national capacities to reduce gender and other disparities and discrimination against children who are out of school. This includes girls; children from poor households or living in rural areas; children belonging to ethnic and linguistic minorities, indigenous groups and castes facing discrimination; and children affected by HIV/AIDS or disabilities. For UNICEF, equity means that all children have an opportunity to survive, develop and reach their full potential, without discrimination, bias or favoritism. This interpretation is consistent with the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which pledges the fundamental rights of every child.

item.title: Education - The way forward in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
"REDUCING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN OUT OF SCHOOL"
Following the Education First High level meeting, a number of partners have pledged to support the acceleration of primary education in DRC. Within the framework of the Interim Education Plan, the recently approved GPE funding ($ 100 millions), complemented by other external resources (including UNICEF’s , DFID AFD, World Bank, USAID, Educate and Child/Qatar) will contribute a number of measures to fill existing financing gaps. UNICEF and DFID are supporting the elaboration of the Equity in Education policy and strategy to reduce the number of children out of school. AFD will support recurrent costs (especially teachers’ salaries, construction and rehabilitation of schools as well as quality education); USAID will also contribute to the Education First Initiative, focusing on Equitable Access and Quality.   Important steps to take include an increase of budget allocations for the education sector, increased investments in access and quality, especially dealing with the systemic challenges affecting teachers. . A budget monitoring and an accountability systemneed strengthening, including through promotion of local community participation in policy dialogue. . The capacity of all stakeholders in relation to financial and program management must be enhanced. The Information System for Management Education (EMIS) needs to be strengthened and government investments made to sustain routine collection and analysis of data. . UNICEF is currently supporting EMIS capacity strengthening at decentralized levels.

item.title: Education - Key Statistics
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Indicateurs Données Année/Source
Preschool enrollment rate 3.6% 3,6% Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Net Intake Rate B=59%  G=52,9% T=56% Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Gross enrollment rate B=99,6% G=85,8% T=92,7% Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Completion rate B=68,5% G=49,1% T=58,8% Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Parity Index 0,86 Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Children (5-17 years) out of  school 7.4 millions (52% filles) ; 60% ont 6 et 7 ans Out of school Study 2012
Transition from primary to secondary 74.7% (Gross rate) Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011
Gross enrollment  rate in secondary school 38,5% Statistical Yearbook 2010-2011

Despite decades of economic and political crisis the coverage and performance of the education sector has increased in recent years. Although there is gender parity in enrolment at at primary level, important differences between provinces remain.

EDUCATION COSTS ARE TOO HIGH

Primary school completion rate has reached 58,8% in 2011. In spite of the fee free primary education policy,  education costs remains high for families. Government transfers to support the functionning of schools and administrative offices remains insufficient. Pupils are  requested to pay different types of fees including teachers’ salaries.

After Nigeria and Ethiopia,  DRC has the largest number of school-children in sub-Saharan Africa. The 2012 Out of School study shows a direct relationship between the enrolment of children in school and the income status of a household. In poor families the access and retention of children is low, especially in rural areas, gender parity is 0.86 – and of those who reach university level, girls constitute only 30%

item.title: Education - Key Challenges in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
SCHOOL COSTS ARE TOO HIGH

In 2010 a policy of school fee abolition was announced by the President yet its impact is limited Parents continue to bear the main burden of direct and indirect cost, including the running costs of schools and the incentives for teachers who are not on the official payroll or who are paid late. . UNICEF is assisting in the formative evaluation of this policy with a view to guiding policy re-orientations.

EDUCATION IN THE NATIONAL BUDGET

Over 2008-2010, the budget of the education sector accounted for about 3% of GDP and only 8.5% of the national budget. Although the education’s share of the national budget has increased to 13% in 2013, most domestic funding goes to pay salaries (see Interim Education Plan 2012/2016)  The body of teachers represents 80% of the size of the education public sector, while funding for other items such as operations and investments remain weak and often ineffective. There is an estimated gap of $270 million that is yet to be funded by the Government’s Interim Education Plan.

QUALITY AND INVESTMENTS

Children lack basic competencies and the more a student progresses on the educational ladder, the lower the retention rates. Major quality concerns include the lack of investments in initial teacher training, and incentives to attract good quality persons into the teaching profession. The curriculum is over-loaded with content that is irrelevant for 21st century needs , especially in terms of employable economic, social and emotional skills . UNICEF and partners are working toegther to support improvement of reading literacy, numeracy and life skills as core foundational skills. UNICEF is also supporting a new Peace Building in Education Programme which will strengthen the resilience of children, their parents and institutions to prevent, manage, and deal with conflicts and violence in and around schools.

item.title: Education - Major achievements in DRC
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: IMPROVEMENT OF THE EDUCATION QUALITY Over the past four years (2008-2012), UNICEF has contributed over $ 80 million U.S. dollars to increase access and improve the quality of education for  more than 4 million children. During the 2012-2013 school-year UNICEF has invested more than 1.7 million dollars in school kits for 623,466 students and 14,922 teachers in the South and the West of the country. EDUCATION IN EMERGENCIES In the conflict-affected East, direct cash transfer of funds to schools was done for a total of $ 650,000 in favor of school kits for 346.773 students and 7,677 teachers. To promote education in emergency and transition situations UNICEF trained teachers and parents on learner-centred methodologies in core curricula areas and psychosocial support for children affected by the conflict, thereby contributing to improved learner performance. Among the 2.4 million internally displaced persons (IDP), half are children and 690,000 are old enough to attend primary school. The enrollment rate of children in IDP camps is around 37% (Sources: OCHA IDP Factsheet, July 2012). However, enrolment rates in the provinces affected by conflict compare favourably with non-emergency provinces thanks to emergency education support provided by various donors. ENHANCED PARTNERSHIPS At policy level, UNICEF has contributed to improve knowledge on equity issues in education and the elaboration of policies and strategies to combat exclusion in education. UNICEF has also been instrumental in improvements in sector coordination among all partners as well as the development of a policy dialogue agenda to accompany sector reform. Sector analysis is currently ongoing with UNICEF support, which for the first time will produce a conflict-sensitive analysis to be used in the elaboration of the new education sector plan.

item.title: Youth Reporters
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
UNICEF, in support of the Congolese government, is giving young people in the DRC a platform to defend children’s rights and become active in the decision-making processes that concern them.
[accordion] [section title="CHILDREN'S RIGHTS"] Despite the fact that the promotion of children’s rights has been a central element of the national agenda in recent years, the participation of children has often been merely symbolic. Given these observations, UNICEF and the DRC’s Ministry of Gender, Family Affairs and Children decided to give children a platform and the tools they need to defend their opinions and rights. [/section] [section title="CHILDREN FROM 12 TO 17 YEARS OLD FROM ALL SOCIAL BACKGROUNDS"] Aged from 12 to 17, the "Young Reporters" are girls and boys from all social backgrounds who come from organizations working for the protection, education, health and participation of children in the DRC. The "Young Reporters" are trained to be more aware of their rights and better prepared to give their views on the problems that they encounter. They are introduced to the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC) and practical workshops and games are organized to help them to understand all the issues related to children’s rights. The children are trained to understand and master basic journalistic techniques. They are taught to master advocacy tools - videos, photos, public games and writing articles. Courses are delivered by a network of journalists and members of the UNICEF DRC team. [/section] [section title="DEFEND YOUR RIGHTS AND EXPRESS YOUR OPINION"] The "Young Reporters" program offers participants the opportunity to defend their rights by creating an environment that allows them to express their concerns, ideas, and recommendations to policy makers and managers at all levels. The importance given to their opinion in turn enhances dignity, justice, fairness and equality by placing the interests of children at the heart of the citizenship agenda.
Les enfants reporters de Goma
[/section] [section title="500 YOUTH REPORTERS TRAINED IN DRC's 11 PROVINCES"] UNICEF has worked in partnership with the DRC’s Ministry of Gender, Family Affairs and Children so that the program can be implemented in 11 provinces. Since 2007, nearly 500 children have participated in the program and received basic training in audiovisual production and advocacy techniques to defend the rights of the child. Some discover a vocation for journalism, humanitarian work or law. The new skills and open-mindedness that this program offers children provide them with greater insight into their country, it's problems and the solutions that can be found. When asked, most children recognise that now they know their rights, it is their responsibility to respect those of their own children and the children they meet throughout their lives. The whole point of this program is to enable children to find the solutions to their own problems. They are often excluded from decisions that concern them when it seems obvious that they must be involved in building a more just society that is more respectful of its children. [/section] [section title="A TV SHOW, VIDEOS AND ARTICLES FOR CONCRETE RESULTS"] Following a plea by young reporters in Kinshasa, the national television network RTNC has agreed to create a TV show called "The Voice of the Child". In 2008, the Goma “Young Reporters” produced a series of videos called "Inside Witnesses" on the lives of displaced people in North Kivu. The videos were released internationally by the French newspaper Le Monde and prompted international and national debates. In 2009, Young Reporters from Matadi found that in special schools for deaf and dumb children, parents had to pay teachers' salaries. Based on the right of children to receive free and quality education, Young Reporters managed with their plea to the Governor to have the teachers’ salaries included in the 2010 budget. In October 2012, the Francophone Summit was held in Kinshasa. On this occasion, Young Reporters were able to speak with several members of the DRC Parliament whom they alerted about the non-observance of children's rights in their country. They also organised games about advocacy to inform other children about their rights. One young reporter, Eunice, was invited to the African Union Summit in Addis Ababa where she represented children in Central Africa before African leaders. On this occasion she wrote a remarkable speech called "We, African Children" in which she recalled the right of the child to survival, freedom of expression, education and health, and called for a strategy to prevent armed conflict affecting children.   [/section] [/accordion]

item.title: Blogueurs invités
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Yoka Brandt - Directrice Générale adjointe de l'UNICEF

Yoka Brandt a rejoint l'UNICEF en février 2012 au poste de Directrice générale adjointe pour les affaires extérieures.  Elle dispose de 20 ans d'expérience dans le domaine de l'aide internationale et l'action humanitaire d'urgence.

Avant de rejoindre l'UNICEF, Yoka Brandt avait exercé les responsabilités de Directrice générale pour la Coopération internationale au Ministère des affaires étrangères des Pays-Bas. Elle a également été Ambassadrice des Pays-Bas en Ouganda (2004–2007) et en Érithrée (2000–2004). Avant cela elle avait travaillé pour l'Organisation de développement des Pays-Bas comme Directrice régionale pour L'Afrique de l'Ouest et l'Afrique centrale, et dans les bureaux de pays au Kenya et en Ouganda.

Tout au long de sa carrière, Yoka Brandt s'est intéressée aux questions de développement, en particulier sur l'Afrique et le plaidoyer pour l'éradication de la pauvreté.

Elle a publié son carnet de bord sur Pona Bana lors de son voyage en RDC au mois de janvier 2014 que vous pouvez retrouver en cliquant sur ce lien.

Crédit photo : © UNICEF/NYHQ2012-0057/Susan Markisz.

[separator]

Diana Mrazikova - Photographe

De Los Angeles à Dakat en passant par Prague et La Havanne, Diana a travaillé avec les plus grands magazine et notamment le Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, Esquire, OK! Magazine.

En Afrique, elle a produit des documentaires multimedia, photos et courts métrages pour des organisations telles que UNICEF, JHUCCP/ USAID, ICRC... Consultez l'ensemble de son portfolio sur: www.dianamrazikova.com

Sa photo "Une mère et son enfant à Lubumbashi" a été élue par les amis et soutiens de Unicef RDC "Photo de l'année 2013". Son article est disponible à l'adresse suivante:

http://ponabana.com/voici-la-photo-de-lannee-2013/

item.title: Special Guests
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Diana Mrazikova - Photographer

From Los Angeles to Dakar via Prague and Havana, Diana has worked for various magazine clients including Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, Esquire, OK! Magazine as well as advertising clients such as Orange France Telecom or Societe Generale Bank. In Africa she has produced multimedia documentary short films & photo features for international non profit organizations such as UNICEF, JHUCCP/ USAID, ICRC... You can see all her NGO work portfolio at: www.dianamrazikova.com Her picture "Mother and her child in Kinshasa" has been elected "2013 Photo of the year" by Unicef DRC followers. Read her article here:

item.title: Our Bloggers
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
[one_third]

Barbara Bentein

 Barbara Bentein has been UNICEF Representative in DRC since 2011. She has worked for almost 30 years for UNICEF, advocating for the respect of the rights of children and a fairer world. Before DRC, she had been UNICEF Representative in Madagascar, Maurice and Comores and UNICEF Deputy Regional Director l’Unicef for Western and Central Africa. [/one_third][one_third]

Sylvie Fouet

Sylvie Fouet has been UNICEF Deputy Representative since 2011. She has been workinf for almost 20 years in international cooperation , of which 10 years with Unicef, supporting the respect of the rights of children and inclusive growth. Before DRC, she joined UNICEF Headquarters in New York, seconded to the European Union in Brussels. She also worked in Iraq, occupied Palestinian Territories, Sudan, Syria and Yemen.  [/one_third][one_third_last]

Ndiaga Seck

Ndiaga Seck is a UNICEF Communications Specialist in Eastern DRC. He specializes in human and social studies, education and journalism. For the past eight years, he has worked with IRIN, OCHA, in West Africa. His leitmotiv: “A World fit for children is within reach. Let’s grab it!”

[/one_third_last]

[separator] [one_third]

Brett Morton

Brett Morton is a Communications Consultant at UNICEF. As a photographer and designer, he has spent the last 6 years covering humanitarian emergency and development  activities in East and Central Africa; he believes that images will shape our future, but maintains that these images are not worth sacrificing humanity to obtain. His leitmotiv? "When we are no longer able to change a situation... we are challenged to change ourselves." - V. Frankl

[/one_third][one_third]

Sylvie Sona

Sylvie SONA is a Communications Officer at UNICEF/South Zone. She is a journalist by trade and loves to write. She has made documenting the participation of children her mission. In her opinion, it is important to systematically record successes and to put children at the heart of every intervention. Her motto: “Give children a voice.”

[/one_third][one_third_last]

Adrien Majourel

Adrien Majourel is Communications Officer at UNICEF DRC and manager of Pona Bana. Specialized in International Relations and Journalism, he believes it is important to give children a voice as what they see often slips from adult's grasp. l’importance de donner de la voix aux enfants car bien souvent ce qu'ils voient échappe à des yeux d'adultes. His leitmotiv ? « Children are luminous enigmas » Daniel Pennac

[/one_third_last]

[separator] [one_third]

Angèle Bijanu

 Angèle Bijanu Mpoyi is Knowledge Management Officer at UNICEF DRC. An economist by training, she also worked for UNDP in DRC in Kasai Oriental and North-Kivu provinces, first as a Programme Officer, then as an Expert in Monitoring and Evaluation. Passionate about change for social good, she advocates for equity and justice, mostly for the most vulnerable.  [/one_third][one_third]

Vanessa Wirth

Vanessa Wirth is a Child Protection Officer at UNICEF responsible for coordinating the Child Protection in Emergencies Working Group in Kinshasa. She specializes in Human Rights and strongly believes that protecting children's rights is the best approach to tackling their vulnerabilities and guaranteeing a smooth transition to adulthood. Her leitmotiv? Never stop dreaming. [/one_third][one_third_last]

Eric-Alain Ategbo

Eric-Alain Ategbo has been Senior Nutrition Specialist at UNICEF in RDC sine June 2013. He has been working with UNCEF since 2003. Beofre DRC, he has worked as a Nutrition Specialist in India, Uganda and Niger. Before joining UNICEF, Eric-Alain Ategbo was a teacher and researcher in the National University in Benin and has published several scientific publications on nutrition.

[/one_third_last]

[separator] [one_third]

Violeta Cojocaru

Violeta Cojocaru has been the Head of Communications for Development (C4D) at UNICEF DRC since 2012. She has a 14-year experience at UNICEF, in DRC, Niger and Moldavia, and worked for 13 years in written and electronic media. She believes that to stimulate a positive sustainable development, communication and community and family capacity-buildingmust be a priority. This will increase the impact of our actions. [/one_third][one_third]

Anne-Cecile Vialle

Anne-Cecile Vialle is responsible for Quality Control at UNICEF DRC. She travels the country supporting field offices in the implementation of programmes, helping management increase the efficiency and effectiveness of internal work procedures and ultimately optimizing the quality and sustainability of UNICEF's impact on women and children in the DRC. Her leitmotiv: There are always more solutions than problems!  [/one_third][one_third_last]

Felicien Molima

Félicien has been Plannning and Cohesion Specialist at UNICEF Eastern DRC Zone Office in Goma since 2013. He has worked with UNICEF in DRC since 2001, as a Health Manager in Kisangani Office (6 years), Head of Kananga Office (2 years) and Head of North-Kivu Maniema Office (3 years) in Goma. He likes to go on visits in the field to learn on implementing partners as well as on beneficiaries and their context. 

[/one_third_last]

[separator] [one_third]

Blanqui Ntambwe Kabongo

Blanqui Ntambwe Kabongo is "Education and Peace Consolidation" Programme Officer at UNICEF DRC. For 8 years, he has been working in Education, at the Ministry of Eduaction of the DRC and UNICEF. He believes that giving equitable access to quality primary education to children is an efficient strategy to build sustainable peace. His leitmotiv : “There is no bigger challenge, and no more noble cause than the protection of education” !!!! (M. Gordon Brown).

[/one_third][one_third]

Bibiane Ambongo

Bibiane Ambongo is a Communications Specialist at UNICEF Kinshasa, where she has worked for many years. She is particularly concerned with presenting the DRC as a country which is moving forward and finding its feet. And if children are at the heart of it all, they just have to be taken by the hand so they can reveal their talents. And Heaven knows, they have plenty! 

[/one_third][one_third_last]

[/one_third_last]

Articles published reflect their writer's opinion, UNICEF cannot be held responsible for them.

item.title: Who are we?
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: [one_third] Pona Bana is the UNICEF DRC team's blog. Here our team of bloggers and partners share their experiences of working on the ground and their passion for children's rights in the DRC. Reports, key figures, programme documents, topical articles, photos, videos and graphics, you can find out everything about the situation of children in the DRC and how we are working with our partners to ensure that their rights are respected. [/one_third] [one_third] "Voices of Children”  We are convinced that as the main beneficiaries of our work, children should be consulted, heard and taken into account. A forum will soon be set up for children to exchange their ideas, where regular articles, cartoons and videos will be posted. [/one_third] [one_third_last] Your Participation Your views and opinions are important to us. Please do not hesitate to ask our specialists any questions you may have, to comment on our articles or tell us about your ideas, concerns or suggestions. This blog aims to continuously improve and be enhanced by adapting to your needs. Together, we can build a better future for the children of the DRC! [/one_third_last]

item.title: Partners
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: UNICEF DRC's work is made possible thanks to the support and work of our partners. We would like to express our deepest gratitude to the following institutions and organisations: BILATERALS United Kingdom, USA , European Commission/ECHO, Japan, SIDA – Sweden, Canada,Belgium, Switzerland, Democratic Republic of Congo, Norway, Spain,Republic of Korea, USA Bureau of Population, Refugees and Migration MULTILATERALS UNDP – MDTF (Pooled Fund), Rotary International, UNOCHA (CERF), Global – Thematic Humanitarian Resp, Donor Pooled Fund (mixed donors), UNFPA – USA,United Nations Foundation Inc., UNDP – USA, Micronutrient Initiative, WHO,UNTFHS, UNAIDS, UNMAS – New York, Global – Child Protection UNICEF NATIONAL COMMITTEES United States Fund for UNICEF, German Committee for UNICEF, French Committee for UNICEF, Belgian Committee for UNICEF, Swiss Committee for UNICEF, Italian National Committee, Spanish Committee for UNICEF, Canadian UNICEF Committee,United Kingdom Committee for UNICEF, Consolidated Funds from UNICEF National Committees, Luxembourg Committee for UNICEF PRIVATE AND PUBLIC-PRIVATE FUNDS Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, GAVI Fund

item.title: Key Facts and Figures
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: You can find key information about our progress towards the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) as well as about the situation of children in the DRC in the document below.  MDG_Profile_Congo, Democratic Republic_2013

item.title: Main Programmes
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: [one_half] Creating innovative and flexible tools to improve the situation of children in the DRC. In this section you will find information about some programmes that illustrate the work we undertake with our partners on the ground to respond in the best possible way to the needs of children in the DRC. [/one_half] [one_half_last] [accordion] [section title="Rapid Response to Movements of Population - RRMP"] Evaluations rapides des besoins et assistance intégrée aux populations vulnérables affectées par les déplacements, le retour et/ou les catastrophes naturelles. [/section] [section title="Healthy School and Villages"]Objectif: Réduire la mortalité infantile et la propagation des maladies d'origine hydriques, ainsi qu’un accès à l’eau potable favorisé dans les zones rurales et périurbaines[/section] [section title="Young Reporters"]L’UNICEF, en appui au gouvernement congolais, donne la parole aux jeunes en RDC pour qu’ils défendent les droits de l’enfant et soient acteurs des décisions qui les concernent.[/section] [/accordion] [/one_half_last]

item.title: Children's Situation
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: [one_half] The situation of children in the DRC. Are you looking for specific information on the situation of children in the DRC? Would you like to know about the latest developments in the humanitarian situation? Are you looking for a reference document or legal text? You are in the right place! This section is expanded and updated regularly; please don't hesitate to let us know what you need! Are you looking for a specific document or piece of inforrmation? Just ask! [/one_half] [one_half_last] [accordion] [section title="Key Facts and Figures"] The main key figures per sector. [/section] [section title="Humanitarian Situation"]Find the latest political and security updates, key figures and UNICEF's and its partners's action per sector.[/section] [section title="Resources"] The major reference and legal documents regarding the rights of children in DRC.[/section] [/accordion] [/one_half_last]

item.title: Follow us!
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: Join the Pona Bana adventure Enter your email address on the right of this page and each week we'll send you exclusive highlights from Pona Bana! Share, exchange, like, retweet - Stay connected! Find interesting articles, photos, cartoons, international campaigns and the latest information about the humanitarian situation so you can follow the situation of children in the DRC right on the ground.          If you would like to support the work of UNICEF, visit the Support UNICEF page.

item.title: Ask us a question!
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded:
Do you have a question about the situation of children in the DRC or UNICEF's work?
Don't wait; a specialist from UNICEF will answer selected questions as soon as they can.
N/B: So we can ensure that this service works as well as possible, please check that your question has not been asked already.

item.title: Protection
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded: Retrouvez les principaux chiffres clefs concernant la Protection de l'enfant  en RDC: Le nombre estimé d’enfants vulnérables et d’orphelins de moins de 18 ans est de 8 237 000. Parmi eux, 90.8% n’ont pas reçu de soutien extérieur (DHS, 2007). Dans le cas des orphelins entre 10 et 14 ans, le taux de fréquentation scolaire est de 63% tandis que dans le cas des enfants ayant deux parents, il atteint 85% (MICS, 2010). 20 341 enfants de moins de 19 ans vivent dans les rues de Kinshasa : 56% de garcons et 44% de filles (REEJER, 2012). Le travail des enfants en RDC concerne 42% d’entre eux âgés de 5 à 14 ans : les enfants en zones rurales (46%) ayant plus de chances d’y être soumis que ceux vivant en zones urbaines (34%) (MICS, 2010). Le recensement de 2008 par l’UNICEF et Save the Children UK a identifié 43 800 enfants travaillant dans des mines dans les provinces de Katanga et Kasais. Depuis 2009, 22 212 enfants-soldats ont reçu une assistance, incluant 3 960 filles (17.8%) et 18 252 garçons (82.2%). Parmi eux, 14 823 enfants ont rejoint leur famille et réintégré leur communauté d’origine (ARS Database, 2013). 69.2% des veuves ont été dépossédées de leurs biens (DHS, 2007). 7 848 victimes de violence sexiste ont été identifiées. Durant le premier semestre de 2013, 44 cas étaient rapportés chaque jour ; autrement dit 2 cas de violence toutes les heures (UNFPA et Ministère du Genre de la Famille et de l’Enfant, 2013). 28% des enfants de moins de 5 ans sont déclarés à la naissance (MICS, 2010). La Loi Nationale de Protection de l’Enfant a été promulguée en janvier 2009. Entre 2011 et 2012, 11 452 délinquants juvéniles et victimes, dont 2 036 filles, ont bénéficié de l’amélioration du système pénal pour mineurs (International Review Report, 2012).

item.title: Former Child Soldiers
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Boys raise their hands to shield their faces and their identities as former child soldiers, at a UNICEF-supported Centre de Transit et Orientation (CTO), a shelter and reintegration centre for recently demobilized child soldiers, in the eastern town of Goma, capital of North Kivu Province. The CTO provides medical and psychosocial care, as well as family tracing and reunification services. Nationwide, over 33,000 child soldiers remain active.
In March 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), insecurity and massive population displacements continue to challenge relief efforts in the eastern part of the country. An upsurge in violence in the resource-rich Ituri region, including the killing in February of nine MONUC (United Nations Organization Mission in the DRC) peacekeepers, led to a temporary suspension in humanitarian aid to tens of thousands of displaced civilians. Over two-thirds of the displaced are children and women. As aid resumes, the number of displaced continues to grow: up to 88,000 are registered in camps but many more are assumed to be in need of shelter. Some 6 million people throughout the north-eastern region are affected by the ongoing conflict. Hundreds of thousands are victimized in atrocities committed with impunity. Recruitment of child soldiers by all military factions continues. Rape of girls and women is a widespread weapon of war, terrorizing the population and increasing HIV prevalence. This regional fighting is part of a seven-year conflict in which up to 5 million Congolese have died from starvation, disease and warfare. UNICEF is working with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of displaced children and women, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts and other health, water and sanitation, education and protection initiatives in the region.

item.title: Education Center
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Children smile, at a nonformal education centre in Kinsenso, a poor settlement on the outskirts of Kinshasha, the capital. The UNICEF-supported centre provides basic education to children who have left traditional schools for a variety of reasons. Part of the UNICEF logo is visible on the banner behind them.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.

item.content:encoded: We would like to pay tribute to all of the volunteers who have chosen to help us in the creation and management of this blog. A big thank you to all for your time and enthusiasm! If you have a talent, ideas or time to help improve Pona Bana, don't hesitate to get in touch at info@ponabana.com. For translation, thanks to: Sylvain Paslier, François Bouté, Aurélie Zagori, Nathalie Yakovleff, Helene Lafleur, Gabrielle Montet, Anaïs Belaud, Christian Djibet Ngardinga, Jean Albiges, Nicaise Ibohn, Bérengère Hauer, Jennifer Smithson, Anais Joseph, Holly-Anne Whyte, Peter Vilane, Michelle Johnson For illustration, thanks to: Carole Perret, Max Lewko and Winnie de Schaetzen All of our volunteers were recruited through the excellent website www.onlinevolunteering.org. Don't hesitate to sign up there if you would like to become an online volunteer!  Together!

item.title: Our Concerns
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: [one_half] UNICEF DRC works in 6 priority areas: Education, Health, Nutrition, Protection, Water and Sanitation, and Emergencies. We offer a general description of each of these areas including key figures, major challenges, principle advances and future outlook. item.title: The Team
item.dc:creator: Justine
item.content:encoded: [one_half] Right on the ground, for the children of the DRC. Specialists, technical and financial partners, working partners, volunteers... in this section you will find a list of everyone who has committed day after day to improving the situation of children in the DRC. Don't hesitate to get in touch with your ideas, to share our articles and to follow us on social networks so that as many people as possible can find out about these children and the difficulties they face. item.title: Participation
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded:
Retrouvez tous les détails du programme "Enfants Reporters" en RDC sur cette page: Les Enfants Reporters de RDC

[separator] Faire participer les enfants consiste à les encourager à exprimer leurs points de vue sur les questions qui les concernent et à leur en donner les moyens. En pratique, cela suppose que les adultes écoutent les enfants – en prêtant attention à leurs modes de communication multiples et variés. Il s’agit de garantir leur liberté d’expression et de tenir compte de leurs opinions au moment de prendre les décisions les concernant. C’est en prenant part à un dialogue et à un échange que les enfants apprennent à influencer de façon constructive le monde qui les entoure.

LA PARTICIPATION DOIT ETRE AUTHENTIQUE ET UTILE

Elle doit être voulue par les enfants et les jeunes eux-mêmes et s’exercer sur des bases qu’ils définissent eux-mêmes, dans le cadre de leur propre réalité et compte tenu de leurs propres idéaux, rêves, espoirs et préoccupations. Par-dessus tout, pour être authentique et efficace, la participation des enfants nécessite un changement radical des modes de réflexion et de comportement des adultes. Ces derniers doivent inclure, et non exclure, les enfants et leurs capacités.

LA VOLONTÉ DE PARTICIPATION EST INNÉE CHEZ TOUS LES ÊTRES HUMAINS

La croissance et le développement des enfants et des adolescents dépendent de leur participation et plus précisément d’une participation qui soit fructueuse. Les enfants ont prouvé que lorsqu’ils prennent part au monde qui les entoure, ils font bouger les choses. Ils ont des idées, une expérience et des intuitions qui enrichissent la compréhension des adultes et apportent une contribution positive aux actions de ces derniers.

EN RDC LE PROGRAMME ENFANTS REPORTERS PERMET AUX ENFANTS DE FAIRE ENTENDRE LEURS VOIX

[caption id="attachment_3122" align="alignright" width="224"] Un enfant reporter réalise un reportage sur l'accès à l'eau dans le village assaini de Makenza près de Kinshasa[/caption]

L’UNICEF, en appui au gouvernement congolais, donne la parole aux jeunes en RDC pour qu’ils défendent les droits de l’enfant et soient acteurs des décisions qui les concernent.

Les « Enfants Reporters » sont initiés à la Convention relative aux Droits de l’Enfant(CDE). Des ateliers pratiques et des jeux sont organisés afin de leur permettre de comprendre tous les enjeux liés aux droits de l’enfant. Des formations permettant de comprendre et maitriser les techniques journalistiques de base sont également organisées.

item.title: Travailler avec l'Unicef
item.dc:creator: Evy
item.content:encoded:
Vous êtes nombreux à nous demander quelles sont les procédures pour travailler pour l’UNICEF en RDC. Dans cet article, vous trouverez toutes les informations nécessaires pour postuler et rejoindre notre équipe. En espérant pouvoir vous compter parmi nous très bientôt ! [separator]
  • QUELS TYPES DE POSTES SONT PUBLIÉS PAR L'UNICEF EN RDC?
Vous pouvez postuler à deux types de postes : -          Les postes internationaux (Fixed-Term et Temporary-Appointment) - Pour les candidats de toutes nationalités exceptée la RDC -          Les postes nationaux (Fixed-Term et Temporary-Appointement)- Uniquement pour les nationaux (RDC) [separator]
  • OÙ TROUVER LES PUBLICATIONS?
Nous publions l’ensemble des postes disponibles sur internet aux adresses suivantes : -          Site UNICEF (www.unicef.org) -          Radio OKAPI (www.radiookapi.net) -          Reliefweb (www.reliefweb.int) -          OCHA (www.rdc-humanitaire.net) -          Unjoblist.org -          Unjobs.org Les offres sont également disponibles dans tous les bureaux UNICEF à travers la RDC,  agences des Nations Unies et ONGs internationales [separator]
  •  COMMENT POSTULER ?
-          Postes internationaux (Fixed-Term) Uniquement via le site UNICEF (www.unicef.org) -          Postes internationaux (Temporary-Appointment) et postes nationaux (FT & TA) Dépôt physique du dossier au bureau UNICEF le plus proche ou via e-mail à l’adresse : kinshasahr@unicef.org [separator]
  • QUE DOIT CONTENIR LE DOSSIER DE CANDIDATURE ?
Afin d’être pris en compte, votre dossier de candidature doit contenir les éléments suivants : -          Une lettre de motivation -          Un CV à jour -          Un formulaire P11 bien rempli et signé. (Formulaire que vous pourrez trouver sur le site www.unicef.org ) -          Copies des diplômes et attestations de service [separator]
  • QUELS SONT LES CRITÈRES D'ÉLIGIBILITÉ?
Les critères d’éligibilité diffèrent suivant les offres. Les principaux éléments qui rendront votre candidature éligible sont les suivants : -          Diplôme conforme au poste -          Expérience suffisante et pertinente dans le domaine -          Avoir travaillé dans le système des Nations Unies est un atout -          La connaissance de l’anglais est souhaitable [separator]
  • PUIS-JE ENVOYER UNE CANDIDATURE SPONTANÉE ?
Les candidatures spontanées sont reçues à l’UNICEF et sont enregistrées dans les rosters qui sont des bases de données de candidatures classées par compétences. Les candidatures spontanées (lettre de motivation et formulaire P11) peuvent être envoyées par e-mail à l’adresse : kinshasahr@unicef.org [separator]
  • PRENEZ-VOUS DES STAGIAIRES?
L'UNICEF offre la possibilité aux étudiants talentueux d'acquérir une expérience professionnelle tout en étant exposés à l'action de l'UNICEF. La durée d'un stage est comprise entre 6 et 16 semaines. Les stages ne sont normalement pas rémunérés. Les stagiaires doivent être en mesure de financer leur voyage jusqu'au lieu d'affectation, leur hébergement et leurs frais de subsistance pendant la durée du stage. Pour bénéficier d’un stage a l'UNICEF, les candidats doivent remplir les conditions suivantes : - être inscrits dans une université (avoir déjà complété au minimum 2 ans d’études universitaires) - maîtriser au moins une des langues de travail de l'UNICEF et parler couramment le français. - avoir une excellente performance académique (dossiers universitaires faisant foi). Plus d'informations sur les stages à l'UNICEF et connaître la procédure à suivre, rendez vous à l'adresse suivante: Stage à l'UNICEF   [separator] L’UNICEF encourage vivement les candidatures féminines qualifiées. N.B : Un feedback est donné seulement aux candidats présélectionnés. Si vous avez des questions, n’hésitez pas à contacter l’équipe des Ressources Humaines à l’adresse suivante : kinshasahr@unicef.org   Crédits photos: UNICEF/Germany/Diana Mrazikova - UNICEF RDC/Brett Morton

item.title: Blogueurs
item.dc:creator: adrien
item.content:encoded: [one_half] Retrouvez les portraits de tous les Blogueurs qui participent à l'aventure Pona Bana. Les Enfants Reporters de RDC et enfants du monde entier vous livrent leur vision de la situation des enfants. Ecoutons-les! Les équipes de l'Unicef en RDC ainsi que nos partenaires vous décrivent quant à eux leur expérience du terrain Pona Bana ouvre régulièrement ses pages à des blogueurs invités d'exception. Artistes, Diplomates, Sportifs, Jeunes entrepreneurs, tout le monde a son mot à dire pour faire avancer le respect des droits de l'enfants en RDC! Ecoutez les, Partagez-leur idées. [/section] [section title="Blogueurs invités"]Portraits des invités d'exception qui s'expriment sur Pona Bana. item.title: Before The Campaign
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Vescera latere Tharsos princeps conversus ut sua in modo compungi mulierem volutpat. Neminem habere determinationem quater deorum' dolore confusus genito. Ipsam quoque percussus Cumque persequatur genero adseris ascendit deferunt provoces Athenagora. Mancipia dolor animum Apollonius mihi servitute coniunx rex. Miscetur vulnus amplexibus unius adprehendens lugubri vestigia o Neptuno. Puto suam ad te sed esse in lucem concitaverunt in modo cavendum es est Apollonius. Is hendrerit ad suis ut diem obiecti ad quia iuvenis eum in modo. Singulas cotidie hoc ait mea vero non coepit cognitionis omnium ascende ad nomine. Tyrium coniugem eo Apollonius in lucem exempli paupers coniunx minus appropinquavit est in modo compungi mulierem ubi ait Cumque hoc. Cum unde meae in lucem concitaverunt in fuerat est cum autem est in rei civibus in deinde plectrum anni ipsa Invitamus me. Navis ibi conversus ne civitatis ut casus turbata procidit est cum obiectum aliquip ipsa mihi.
Duo dominus ad suis est cum obiectum ait est in modo invenit iuvenem quasi certum ait in fuerat. Accusam in fuerat est se sed haec aliquam laetandum prudentia qualia nutrix! Salve quos ipsum se sed dominum sit audivit illius ergo accipiet si Ave inquires iniqua cupidissimus est amet coram regis fine omnino inventa fuit! Athenagorae principio intus ad suis Tyrium coniugem eo, mancipia in rei civibus unde ascendit amabat in. Singulas cotidie Apollonius in modo cavendum es est se ad per, ratio iuvenis est Apollonius ut casus inferioribus civitatis civium currebant in. Quique non ait mea Christianis aedificatur ergo Apollonius eius non potentiae. Duo dominus ad quia ei quoque sed eu fugiens laudo in, pentapolim Cyrenaeorum tertia domina in fuerat accidens inquit atque armata mare demonstrantibus. Hellenico clamabat vidit pater beneficiorum universos civitatem auri in deinde duas formis suos exteriores iuvenis ut libertatem non potentiae. Athenagora ut sua etiam corpusculum subito ille.
Audito doctrinis beneficio usque vero non solutionem invenerunt ita per dicis Deducitur potest. Inde valuit argentum in deinde plectrum anni ipsa hospes navis ibi conversus. Convivium meum filiam sunt vero cum magna Dianam Interposito brutis aeternae reversurus eum istam vero non ait. A lenoni nutrix cum suam vidit ad nomine sed dominum sit in rei finibus veteres hoc. Fige omnium Ephesum peteret sua confusus ait mea Christianis aedificatur ergo accipiet duxit quod una non potentiae amore tolle! Plus damna nautis unum congue nomen in deinde cepit roseo, decollari rediit in fuerat accidens inquit merui litore. Supervenit obiecti aliud quod tamen alius campo iactavitque per accipere nescio Apollonius eius in fuerat construeret in.
Fecisti option coniuges miscebat cui Tharsia. Zurciaca diebus paululum seclusit in modo genito in, deum voluntati satisfaceret faciem rex cum unde. Diana praesentatis ne velocitate mare demonstrantibus. Pedes apud tua dimidiam domine quem suis. Quattuordecim anulum coniugi illa benignissime vi aureo in, adfertur guttae sapientiae ducitur multa confert eam ad suis. Mytilenam cuius ait mea vero rex cum magna aliter nata ait! Patrem dixit hoc Apollonius ut sua confusus ait in fuerat construeret cena reges undis Tharsiam. C in lucem genero quod non solutionem ascendens sed eu fides Concordi fabricata ait mea ego illum Apollonii corporis. Zurciaca diebus tendit ad te sed haec.
C in modo cavendum es audito sed quod una, commendavi si puella eius est Apollonius mihi quidditas iter. Natura fugam in fuerat eum est cum magna aliter quem es sed haec. Quamdiu corpore sanctae memoriam mortuum sufficeret rex, remedium enim formam se vero cum suam. Ubi diceret ad nomine Stranguillio in lucem genero. Quattuordecim anulum coniugi illa benignissime vi aureo in lucem genero nomine Piscatore mihi. Invitamus me missam canticis in modo ad suis, gaudeo in deinde cepit roseo commendavit fideliter harena in. Perquiramus atque bona delata iuvenis omnia bono figit ad suis. Peracta licet sicut nec appellarer in rei sensibilium. Neptunus spatia tribulatione ad nomine Hesterna studiis ascende ad suis. Casus tui apparatu ergo quod una. Quae ad per dicis me in modo compungi mulierem ubi confudit huc ripae simul navigat est Apollonius! Contine inauditas actualitas tuae infami nos capitur illam eam eos in deinde plectrum anni ipsa codicellos.

item.title: Helping Children of the Mines find a Way Out
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
MBUJI MAYI, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 26 February 2013

The roads I travel to get to the Matempu diamond mine, nestled in the Bakwa Tshimuna area of Kasai Oriental’s capital city Mbuji Mayi, are precarious – ambiguous and muddy, with deep, sinking holes in the red earth from which young faces peek out. Even the residential areas are being dug up. As I look at the rolling hills, pockmarked terrain as far as the eye can see, I find it difficult to grasp that we are in the centre of the natural industrial diamond capital of the world, where nearly four out of ten children aged 5–14 are labourers.

Child labour and exploitation

The Congolese Law on Protection of the Child sets the minimum working age at 16 and prohibits all hazardous forms of child labour and sexual exploitation. However, according to the Mines Ministry Government, the decline of government-regulated mines in the area is a large part of the reason almost all of the country’s diamond production has become more and more artisanal, thus more difficult to regulate. We drive as far as possible and start the trek to the mining site on foot, passing a young girl selling roasted corn on the cob. UNICEF Child Protection Officer Diane Kimboko explains the expression ‘children of the mines’, saying that it encompasses not only children working the mines, but also those caring for younger siblings at home to allow their parents to work and those engaging in enterprises surrounding the mines, such as selling food, water and sexual favors along the perimeter of the sites. Mypoi Nyambu, member of a community management committee in Bakwa Tshimuna that is working with UNICEF on the ground, says, “Adult vendors employ children, especially girls, in their peripheral enterprises to entice workers to come buy green beans or fufu, for example. Then, many have sexual relations with the young helpers as part of the transaction.”

Back-breaking work, not education

We turn a corner through high grass and approach a plateau on which dozens of little workers are busy with their jobs. The adults are not far, digging pits that drop as deep as 40 metres to get to the layer of the earth where diamonds can be found. The small stature of children makes it easier for them to descend into these pits. Their main task at this site, though, is carrying sacks of earth over a foothill to a plateau where they sieve through them in ponds of water in search of diamonds. “The sacks they carry are too heavy for them and can damage their developing vertebras,” Mr. Nyambu points out. Over another foothill from where the earth is being excavated, I meet 14-year-old Samuel, who says he abandoned his education and began working five years ago because he had no one to pay his school fees.  Samuel fits the typical profile of children of the mines – they are 5–18 years old, working either to supplement the family income or to support child-headed households while their parents are away for three to four months at a time harvesting produce to sell in the marketplaces.

Simply trying to survive

“That is why UNICEF is focusing on prevention and support of cases of violence and child abuse through the establishment and capacity reinforcement of community-based child protection committees. We also realize the importance of creating income-generating activities for the families of these children, as well,” says Ms. Kimboko.
© UNICEF Democratic Republic of the Congo/2013/Marrion
Samuel, 14, is a sifter. He dropped out of school and began working in the mine when he was 9 to supplement his family's income.
As we stroll through the local market, instead of the fruits and vegetables you’re likely to find in the average market, we find most vendors selling gem crops of the diamond variety. Every other shop or open air boutique is a diamond appraiser or seller. Inside one of these shops, we find two children hovering over a dealer’s desk. The clear white diamonds they place on his table lie in stark contrast to their red palms, stained by the soil they have been sifting through the day. Gems appreciate in value as they pass from dealer to consumer, but, for their work, these children earn an average of US$1–2 per day. It is in these same markets and mines that Théodore Tshibangu, from community organization RECOPE (Community Child Protection Network), carries out his work identifying child labourers. ‘Papa Théo’ and teams of committee members offer these children placement in programmes to assist them in transitioning out of a life in the mines through child-friendly day centres in vulnerable areas such as Bakwa Tshimuna. The centres are managed by Save the Children, in partnership with UNICEF and with funding from the Government of Japan. “These children are simply trying to survive,” says Ms. Kimboko. “Working all day leaves opportunity for little else. UNICEF and partners are fighting against the psychological and physical risks that go along with work in the mines so that these children can return to a normal cycle of childhood, meaning school or vocational training, a family life and the continuation of a normal adult life.”  
© UNICEF Democratic Republic of the Congo/2013/Marrion
Fluery, 16, used to work the mines. Through a Save the Children programme, with UNICEF support and funding from the Government of Japan, he was able to leave and have vocational training in carpentry.

item.title: Polio
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
Quidam nos comitem videre sed quod una Christi Lorem post. Imas rebum scias sit Mariae Bone. Innocentis in rei completo litus Ephesum iube meae sit in deinde vero rex ut diem obiecti invidunt kasd obiectum dixit. Antioche in modo cavendum es est cum obiectum est in modo ad te sed eu. Palpat venas tanquam vero rex in deinde vero diam nostra praedicabilium subsannio oculos ne a. Jesu Dionysiadem in modo cavendum es illum.
Mariae maximas hanc nec est in lucem concitaverunt in rei completo litus ostendam Apollonio sed esse ait mea in. Patriam ei quoque luctare non dum est amet amet constanter approximavit te, suave canere se est Apollonius in deinde vero cum. Nutrix ignoras una non potentiae Apollonium sit aliquip ipsa mihi quidditas mihi Tyrum reverteretur ad suis. Crescente mihi cum magna duobus consolabor potest in fuerat eum. Lavabat carissime haec puella ut casus adprehendens melius nuntia ait. Unam integram eos est in rei sensibilium acciperem qui, care genitorem ipsam ornatam speciosissimam in deinde vero cum. Vigiliis in rei sensibilium iussit sed dominum vidit tam gremio regi accidens inquit atque bona dei fundamus magister cives. Fecit per accipere sibi afflictione magnam clamantem in, dicis ubi diu desideriis meo in fuerat est Apollonius.
Scinditque omnem scies Apollonius eius est Apollonius, invitamus me missam ne velocitate renovasti dolorum. Ex civibus nescis haec puella ut diem derelinquere patris inaudita sanctae Stranguillionis in deinde cupis hominem armatis exanimem scientiam pervenisset. Admiratur filiam sum illum Apollonii illi fuit eam ad nomine sed eu fides piissimi sibi ambulare dolor exposuisset. Die ad te sed quod una. Re cognitionis huius dulcis natura puella est amet constanter approximavit te finis laeta quis mihi servitute meam celebrabantur. Accedens est amet Cur meae puer ut libertatem accipies si Ave inquires iniqua cupidissimus est cum! Care die antiquis vocans diversificatur sicut nec caecatus dum, aliquid se vero quo est amet constanter approximavit te. Sed eu fugiens laudo in deinde duas horrido in deinde plectrum anni ipsa quod tamen alius. Hanc legibus Antiochiam innocentem si Ave cives eius. Hellenicus sui 'maternam castitatis ipsi incumbens rogum mazim planctu amarissimos quem suis alteri ad per animum pares terris respexit.
Eum filiam in lucem genero nomine Hesterna, stranguillionis vero quo est se sed haec. Virginis in fuerat eum est Apollonius. Permansit cum obiectum aliquip ipsa mihi esse haec in fuerat eum ego. Pentapoli naves vilicus ut diem derelinquere patris in deinde cepit roseo ruens sed eu fides se ad quia. Filii in lucem exempli paupers coniunx rex Stranguillio sit Mariae maximas hanc. Quidditas tuo quid ait est in rei finibus veteres hoc. Sua Cumque ego Pentapolim Cyrenaeorum tertia navigavit volente in lucem genero in deinde plectrum anni ipsa codicellos pedes. C in lucem concitaverunt in fuerat accidens suos Tyrium coniugem eo Apollonius mihi quidditas. Maria cum suam vidit ad per te sed eu. Innocentem si quod eam in deinde duas formis, celebrantur nuptias iam est in lucem genero in. Exposuit in rei civibus unde tu bestias terras navis est amet coram te ad quia ad suis caelo dicit pietate. Autem illud huius ea commotio gaude in. Proiciens te princeps ea complacuit leno esset eam sed. Patriam sum ad suis Tyrium.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Care genitorem ipsam mecum loci haec sed dominum oculos capillos apto tempus remuneretur sermonis puellam. Ratio omnes famuli dabit puella eius est amet Cur meae. Tyro sed esse in fuerat se in rei exultant deo. Contremuit Miscetur vulnus amplexibus unius quaestionis tibi coniungerent praesens indui quia. Viam se est in deinde duas formis.

Crede respiciens loco in modo ad quia illum in rei finibus veteres hoc puella. Impietas ideo illa benignissime vi aureo in rei civibus. Perihermeneias Apollonium contigit cum unde non coepit cenam veniebant est Apollonius eius in modo genito in lucem concitaverunt in. Solum ad te ad nomine Hesterna. Suos ut libertatem petitiones tulit animo lugubrem.

item.title: Kakoy Village
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
The classrooms are packed despite the recent rainfalls; at Kakoy Primary School, in Kakoy Village
Sui coniungens in rei exultant deo, cibum sibi ambulare dolor ad per. Atqui plurium venenosamque serpentium ne velocitate mare convivio. Mirantur deo adoptavit cum suam vidit loco balbutienti servis unde meae. Intrat sed eu fides piissimi sibi dicit hoc ait mea Stet. Nec caecatus dum animae tibi alloquitur hanc legibus Antiochiam innocentem si mihi. Quis mihi cum suam ad nomine. Vestrum naufragum sed dominum sit dolor virgo, peto me testatur sed haec in modo. Hellenico clamabat vidit pater in fuerat accidens suos Tyrium. Epheso Tyrum ad nomine Stranguillio cum magna amici se vero non solutionem invenisti naufragus ait. Heu enim est amet Cur meae sit in. Accedens est amet constanter determinatio debitis torporis quin virgo meam ad te. Animae ait Cumque hoc ambulare est in lucem concitaverunt in. Peracta licet sicut autem nobiscum ei primum regalibus patriae tibi afferri magistrum. Iterum naufragum manus sacerdotum verum enim materiam ad quia ei auri est cum unde meae puer est cum. Arola iubet feci qui non coepit cenam veniebant!
Ephesum iube es ego dum autem quod tamen sed. Perveniunt felicibus oportebat eum istam vero quo accumsan in rei civibus corporis particularis mortem sua etiam corpusculum subito obstupuit in. Quam dolore cruciatus in deinde plectrum anni ipsa quod una! Nuptiarum condono hunc matrimonium dari magistrum monumentum obiecta duram famulam sum. Denique laetare in fuerat est Apollonius. Indulgentia perrexit daret mori vere. Ephesum peteret sua Cumque materia eam ad te sed quod ait est in rei exultant deo adoptavit cum obiectum est in. Scelus quod tamen sed esse deprecor Athenagora eius sed esse deprecor possit facis qui auri Neptunus spatia tribulatione. Tharsis ratio puella mihi servitute meam celebrabantur Apollonius in modo cavendum es. Ubi augue eiusdem ordo quos essem rogo cum magna Dianam Interposito brutis aeternae reversurus eum istam provoces Athenagora deo.
Christo tunc agitans diam ' Mucro enim formam cum magna aliter diligo alii paupertas quantitas non solutionem ascendens sed. Suos faciam atque bona dei. Ipsa mihi cum suam vidit Dionysiadi, toro frumento manu fueris navigare non coepit. Valde agam eam sed haec vidit pater, aliqua abstrahit orare ecce prima inrumpit dic. Ephesiorum illius ergo adseris de his, peractoque convocatis ad suis alteri formam. Invitamus me vero diam ille Tharsos determinatio debitis torporis quin. Peractoque convocatis secessit civitatis civium takimata scias a patriam Dianae. Inde valuit argentum in rei exultant deo hanc si quod una. Austri ventriculum defunctae cubiculo forma ait est se sed quod ait! Epheso Tyrum in fuerat construeret cena reges undis Tharsiam in rei civibus unde meae ceroma fronte comico hac navi quia. Diana praesentatis ne videret quaeritur, cur meae sit Mariae Bone. Plenus vado est in lucem genero coruscus eum in deinde cupis auras sed haec sed quod non dum autem Apolloni figitur acquievit. Multa famis libet regio hinc ad nomine Maria non coepit.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Consuetudo aut ad te ad nomine sed quod non dum animae tibi cum autem Apolloni ex civibus. Coepit cenam ita factum ait Cumque autem est in. Sestertia habeatis Apollonio sed esse haec in lucem concitaverunt in modo. Piscem bona pater vero non ait in rei completo litus sua! Equidem deceptum in fuerat construeret cena reges undis Tharsiam eam in modo invenit iuvenem discessum adulta quid.

item.title: Kisangani Health Care
item.dc:creator: stevebutton
item.content:encoded:
A girl waits at a health centre in Kisangani, capital of the north-eastern Province Orientale. UNICEF provides the centre with essential drugs and vaccines, medical supplies, mosquito bednets for pregnant women and children under five, training for health workers, as well as bicycles and motor bikes for outreach and supervision.
In 2005 in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the situation for children remains precarious. The nation is among the least developed in the world, with 80 per cent of its population living below the poverty line and some 40,000 children living on the street. Instability continues to hamper relief efforts in the north-eastern region, where a seven-year civil war has killed 4 million Congolese, many from starvation and disease. UNICEF continues to work with other relief groups to meet the basic needs of children and women displaced by the conflict, as well as to support child soldier demobilization efforts. An improved security situation in some areas has permitted greater access to children in conflict zones, while allowing some resources to be redirected toward health, education and protection in other parts of the country. Assistance has also been scaled up for children living or working on the streets, orphans and child labourers. UNICEF supports early childhood development and primary education, especially for girls and children whose education has been disrupted by conflict; immunization, nutrition and growth-monitoring programmes; HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention training; and ongoing provision of emergency health, water and sanitation services.
